text: I don’t follow them right away. That knot of unease in my chest feels like a nail—if I don’t pull it out, I won’t sleep tonight.
“You two go on ahead. I’ll… check if there’s another exit here.”
Lucia freezes, then immediately shakes her head. “No! This place is too dangerous—”
Alicia turns her face slightly, her voice cold and decisive. “One minute.”
She doesn’t look back, but she allows it—as if she’s long since grown used to someone stopping here to “take one more look.”
I crouch down, pretending to adjust my bootlaces, my eyes sweeping over the remaining traces of the formation.
The blue glow on the ground should have faded by now, yet a few thin lines are still slowly retracting—like a wound stitching itself shut.
In the corner of the wall, there’s a circular patch of scrape marks—the exact same shape as the ring-shaped token in her palm.
I reach out and brush the marks with my fingers. A strange warmth lingers—like metal freshly touched by a branding iron.
Even stranger: along the edge of the formation, there’s a line carved so faintly it’s almost invisible, as if someone kept tracing the same number again and again with the tip of a blade.
I lean closer, using the remaining light to make it out—it’s “37.”
“...They didn’t carve this.”
Lucia holds her breath. “What did you see?”
Alicia finally turns back. Her gaze lands on the carved marks and pauses there for half a second.
“Don’t touch it.”
Her voice is quiet, but it carries more weight than any command—closer to a warning.
“You’ve been here many times, haven’t you?”
She doesn’t answer. She only looks away. “Time’s up. Let’s go.”
We leave the underground chamber behind. Snow and fog rush in, and somehow it feels like breathing again.
Lucia whispers, “Did you just see… a number?”
“Yeah.”
Alicia cuts us off. “Don’t discuss it on the road.”
The inn’s lights glow through the fog. When the door closes, the outside world feels sealed away.
